messageBody:
People,

Firstly let me say that I'm the lead developer of Clover, so no
points for guessing which tool I think is better :-)

Without wanting to post a blatant Ad for Clover, i'd like to point
out some features that we think sets Clover apart:

1. Price. Starting at US$125 for a Developer License, Clover is ALOT
cheaper than its competitors. Return On Investment is a no-brainer -
if Clover helps you find and fix one bug that otherwise would have
made it into production, its easily paid for itself.

2. Ant integration. Because Clover plays nicely with Ant, it can be
integrated into your projects build scripts and run automatically, as
part of a continuous integration effort.

3. Reporting. Clover reporting is the most accurate because we parse
your source to produce them. This differentiates us from byte-code or
JDPA based tools that are not always accurate in mapping back to the
source. Reports can be produced in XML or HTML, and (in Version 1.1,
coming soon) in PDF. Version 1.1 will also provide summary historical
reporting over the lifetime of your project - Something that pointy
headed manager types will love to look at.

4. Container friendliness. Clover will happily work with applications
running inside an Application Container (eg. a J2EE server). Clover
doesn't care what VM you use either (as long as its 1.3 or greater).

As Scott points out, Clover uses Source-code instrumentation. This
means you need to do a coverage build to measure coverage. So this
means Clover isn't for everyone. As a Java Development shop, we have
deliberately written Clover with developers in mind.

Cheers,
-Brendan

----
Brendan Humphreys
Lead Developer
Clover Development Team
http://www.thecortex.net/clover
